content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays four main fragments of fibro-adipose tissue. Three of the fragments are pale and predominantly composed of fat. However, the fragment in the lower right quadrant is markedly different, containing a large, dense, and basophilic (dark purple) nodular area. This is highly suspicious for a lymph node extensively replaced by metastatic tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because it is the most visually striking and suspicious region on the entire slide. The high cellularity and dark staining (basophilia) seen at low power are classic signs of malignancy, strongly suggesting this is a positive lymph node. The primary task is to confirm the presence of metastasis in lymph nodes, and this area is the most likely candidate. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. I can see poorly formed, back-to-back glandular structures infiltrating the tissue. The tumor cells exhibit significant atypia, with large, hyperchromatic (darkly stained), and pleomorphic nuclei. There is a desmoplastic stromal reaction (dense fibrous tissue) surrounding the malignant glands, which is a typical response to invasion. The overall features are those of a lymph node largely effaced by metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
